bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, January 13, 1915

div1.p: LePrince discusses malaria distribution in southern states, and field work to eradicate mosquito larvae.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, January 13, 1915
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
1820 State St
New Orleans
Jan 13/15
Dear Doctor Carter
div1.p:
Your letter came yesterday and I spoke to
Dr von Ezdorf this morning and he says he would be
willing for me to take leave of absence if I care to
which of course I do. He says I would probably
be able also to get leave of absence when court is in session
in order to testify as to findings.

I do hope that you will get the opportunity to
get a good rest.

We have had it very warm up to today, it has
been between 70°F & 80° quite often lately and
the crucians are thriving on it. Within a block
of Tulane University I took 116 adult larvae in ten feet
of ditch yesterday in 45 minutes and did not count
half grown ones or smaller-. Saraphora or something
like them were in same ditch in large numbers,

I am on the lookout for punctipennis but have
not bred any out yet. Adults of quads are now relative
ly scarce, adults of Crucians in large tremendous numbers
for New Orleans. Am just now testing some
NaHSO4 (Nitre Coke) a biproduct of Aetna Explosives Co
at Birmingham. Want to get its relative value-
B20
2
as a larvacide - Cost is $2 a ton F O B, Birmingham Ala.
It is slow acting and kills culex larvae more rapidly
than anopheles larvae. As soon as I get its relative
value compared with other larvacides, if of any value
will send you data-. Am having several small
concrete shell tanks made to test larvacides in.
The malaria distribution this past Summer is
of interest - Emporia Virginia as you remember
had a large amount - Tuscaloosa Ala an unus
ual amount, and Dr von Ezdorf says it was
so at other points (I think including Dallas Texas)
apparently there are seasons particularly favorable to malaria
transmission and it might possibly be that
there may be something there that is not thoroughly
understood - I mean with the same number
of no anopheles might we get more able to become
infected one year than another-.

In thinking over other matters or possibly it was
suggested to me, that brackish water anopheles - those
bred in such water may not be able to carry malaria
I don't know whether they have been tried out - its
a flighty thought - but I don't know-!
I am returning Mr Whitmans letter enclosed-

Mrs LePrince joins me in sending best wishes to you
and all your nice family-.

I have gained eleven pounds since I recovered
and do hope you will beat my record in
recovering-.
